title: A tutorial on using the suddengains R package
text: vignette shows suddengains R package can used help methods research studies looking sudden gains described Tang DeRubeis (1999). theoretical background sudden gains might helpful use package can found paper Wiedemann et al. (2020). following vignette illustrates main functions package using example data set sgdata.

title: A tutorial on using the suddengains R package
text: two interactive tables depression rumination scores data set (sgdata) comes suddengains package. data automatically loaded together package running library(suddengains). measured construct contains baseline measure (s0), twelve weekly measures therapy (s1 s12), two follow-measures (fu1 fu2). Note values measure missing, shown empty cells. example missing value see bdi_s2 id = 2 table .

title: A tutorial on using the suddengains R package
text: package offers two methods select cases calculation sudden gains. "pattern": cases providing enough data apply Tang DeRubeis (1999) criteria selected "min_sess": cases minimum number available data points (specified min_sess_num) selected default argument return_id_lgl set FALSE, adds new variable named sg_select end data frame specified data argument. newly calculated variable sg_select logical indicates whether case selected (TRUE) selected (FALSE) based method specified. argument return_id_lgl set TRUE, id variable specified id_var_name new variable sg_select returned output function. following code shows select cases based "pattern" method save object called sgdata_select. function goes data selects cases least one following data patterns. Note: xn-2 xn+3 consecutive data points primary outcome measure. “x” = Present data; “.” = Missing data. “x” represents available data examined possible pregain session.
code: # 1. method = "pattern" select_cases(data = sgdata,              id_var_name = "id",              sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3", "bdi_s4",                               "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6", "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8",                               "bdi_s9", "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),              method = "pattern",              return_id_lgl = FALSE)  # 2. method = "min_sess" select_cases(data = sgdata,              id_var_name = "id",              sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3", "bdi_s4",                               "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6", "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8",                               "bdi_s9", "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),              method = "min_sess",              min_sess_num = 9,              return_id_lgl = TRUE) sgdata_select <- select_cases(data = sgdata,                               id_var_name = "id",                               sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3", "bdi_s4",                                                "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6", "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8",                                               "bdi_s9", "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),                               method = "pattern",                               return_id_lgl = FALSE) %>%                   dplyr::filter(sg_select == TRUE) #> The method 'pattern' was used to select cases. #> See help('select_cases') for more information.

title: A tutorial on using the suddengains R package
text: function calculates cut-value use first sudden gains criterion based Reliable Change Index (RCI, Jacobson Truax 1991). following 5 elements returned function sd: Standard deviation manually entered using sd argument standard deviation values specified data_sd reliability: Reliability measure manually specified reliability internal consistency (Cronbach’s alpha) calculated item--item data specified data_reliability. standard_error_measurement: Standard error measurement, see formula : standard_error_measurement=sd×1−reliability \text{standard_error_measurement} = {\text{sd}} \times \sqrt{1-\text{reliability}} standard_error_difference: Standard error difference two test scores, see formula : standard_error_difference=2×(standard_error_measurement)2 \text{standard_error_difference} = \sqrt{2\times (\text{standard_error_measurement})^2} reliable_change_value: Value considered reflect reliable change measure (Jacobson Truax 1991). value calculated using: reliable_change_value=1.96×standard_error_difference\text{reliable_change_value} = 1.96 \times \text{standard_error_difference} last element list sg_crit1_cutoff can used cut-value first sudden gains criterion.
code: # Define cut-off value for first SG criterion # The sd and the reliability are specified manually define_crit1_cutoff(sd = 10.5,                     reliability = 0.931)  # The reliability is specified manually # The sd gets calculated from variable "bdi_s0" in "sgdata"  define_crit1_cutoff(data_sd = sgdata$bdi_s0,                     reliability = 0.931)

title: A tutorial on using the suddengains R package
text: identify sudden gains/losses can use identify_sg identify_sl functions. functions return data frame new variables indicating -session interval whether sudden gain/loss identified. example variable sg_2to3 holds information whether sudden gains occurred session two three, two pregain three postgain session.

text: argument crit123_details = TRUE returns additional information whether three sudden gains criteria met. information can found section “Adaptations original sudden gains criteria” . wish analyse sudden gains occur immediately first session, include option specify baseline measure sg_var_list (example "bdi_s0") set identify_sg_1to2 == TRUE. allow identification sudden gains session 1 session 2, provided data baseline measure first session available.

previous_headings: Identification of sudden gains > Identify sudden gains and losses
what: Adaptations to the original sudden gains criteria
title: A tutorial on using the suddengains R package
text: package includes options modifying omitting three original sudden gains criteria suggested Tang DeRubeis (1999): cut-value clinically meaningful change measure used identify sudden gains specified using argument sg_crit1_cutoff. omit first criterion identifying sudden gains, argument can ‘switched ’ using sg_crit1_cutoff = NULL. minimum percentage drop pre- post-gain session specified using argument sg_crit2_pct. default minimum 25% drop, .e. sg_crit2_pct = 0.25. omit second criterion identifying sudden gains, argument can ‘switched ’ using sg_crit2_pct = NULL. third criterion can ‘switched ’ using sg_crit3 = FALSE. also possible change significance level (α\alpha) used determine critical value based student t distribution, default sg_crit3_alpha = 0.05.
code: # This example only uses the first and second sudden gains criteria  # All following examples work the same for the "identify_sl()" function # The argument "crit123_details = TRUE" returns details about each between session interval for each criterion. # Details about the third criterion will show NAs for each between session interval because it's not being used (sg_crit3 = FALSE) identify_sg(data = sgdata,             sg_crit1_cutoff = 7,             sg_crit2_pct = 0.25,             sg_crit3 = FALSE,             id_var_name = "id",             sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3", "bdi_s4",                              "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6", "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8",                              "bdi_s9", "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),             identify_sg_1to2 = FALSE,             crit123_details = TRUE)  # This example only uses the first, second, and a modified third sudden gains criterion (sg_crit3_alpha = 0.01) identify_sg(data = sgdata,             sg_crit1_cutoff = 7,             sg_crit2_pct = 0.25,             sg_crit3 = TRUE,             sg_crit3_alpha = 0.01,             id_var_name = "id",             sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3", "bdi_s4",                              "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6", "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8",                              "bdi_s9", "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),             identify_sg_1to2 = FALSE,             crit123_details = TRUE)  # This example only uses the first criterion and a modified second criterion (50%)  identify_sg(data = sgdata,             sg_crit1_cutoff = 7,             sg_crit2_pct = 0.50,             sg_crit3 = FALSE,             id_var_name = "id",             sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3", "bdi_s4",                              "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6", "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8",                              "bdi_s9", "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),             identify_sg_1to2 = FALSE,             crit123_details = TRUE)  # This example only uses the first criterion # Details about the second and third criterion will show NAs for each between session interval identify_sg(data = sgdata,             sg_crit1_cutoff = 7,             sg_crit2_pct = NULL,             sg_crit3 = FALSE,             id_var_name = "id",             sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3", "bdi_s4",                              "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6", "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8",                              "bdi_s9", "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),             identify_sg_1to2 = FALSE,             crit123_details = TRUE)  # This example only uses the first criterion # Details about the second and third criterion will show NAs for each between session interval identify_sg(data = sgdata,             sg_crit1_cutoff = 7,             sg_crit2_pct = NULL,             sg_crit3 = FALSE,             id_var_name = "id",             sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3", "bdi_s4",                              "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6", "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8",                              "bdi_s9", "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),             identify_sg_1to2 = FALSE,             crit123_details = TRUE)

what: Check a specific intervals for a sudden gain/loss
title: A tutorial on using the suddengains R package
text: function check_interval() can used examine whether specific -session interval sudden gain/loss.
code: # Check interval for sudden gain using all 3 criteria # No missing data, alpha = 0.05 check_interval(pre_values = c(32, 31, 33),                post_values = c(5, 6, 7),                sg_crit1_cutoff = 7,                sg_crit2_pct = .25,                sg_crit3 = TRUE,                sg_crit3_alpha = .05,                identify = "sg") #> First, second, and third sudden gains criteria were applied. #> The critical value for the thrid criterion was adjusted for missingness. #> # Check sudden gain #> ## Met Criterion 1: YES #> ## Met Criterion 2: YES #> ## Met Criterion 3: YES #> ## Sudden gain: YES #>  #> # Detailed output #> ## Criterion 1: Cut-off: 7  #> ## Criterion 2: Percentage change threshhold: 25 % #> ## Criterion 3: Adjusted: YES, Critical value: 2.776 #> ## Number of pre gain values present: 3 #> ## Number of post gain values present: 3 #> ## Mean of pre gain values: 32 #> ## Mean of post gain values: 6 #> ## SD of pre gain values: 1 #> ## SD of post gain values: 1  # Check interval for sudden gain using all 3 criteria # No missing data, alpha = 0.01 check_interval(pre_values = c(32, 31, 33),                post_values = c(5, 6, 7),                sg_crit1_cutoff = 7,                sg_crit2_pct = .25,                sg_crit3 = TRUE,                sg_crit3_alpha = .01,                identify = "sg") #> First, second, and third sudden gains criteria were applied. #> The critical value for the thrid criterion was adjusted for missingness. #> # Check sudden gain #> ## Met Criterion 1: YES #> ## Met Criterion 2: YES #> ## Met Criterion 3: YES #> ## Sudden gain: YES #>  #> # Detailed output #> ## Criterion 1: Cut-off: 7  #> ## Criterion 2: Percentage change threshhold: 25 % #> ## Criterion 3: Adjusted: YES, Critical value: 4.604 #> ## Number of pre gain values present: 3 #> ## Number of post gain values present: 3 #> ## Mean of pre gain values: 32 #> ## Mean of post gain values: 6 #> ## SD of pre gain values: 1 #> ## SD of post gain values: 1  # Check intervall for sudden gain using only third criterion # Some missing data, alpha = 0.01 check_interval(pre_values = c(NA, 31, 33),                post_values = c(5, NA, 7),                sg_crit1_cutoff = NULL,                sg_crit2_pct = NULL,                sg_crit3 = TRUE,                sg_crit3_alpha = .01,                identify = "sg") #> Third sudden gains criterion was applied. #> The critical value for the thrid criterion was adjusted for missingness. #> # Check sudden gain #> ## Met Criterion 1: NA #> ## Met Criterion 2: NA #> ## Met Criterion 3: YES #> ## Sudden gain: YES #>  #> # Detailed output #> ## Criterion 1: Cut-off: Criterion 1 was not applied #> ## Criterion 2: Percentage change threshhold: Criterion 2 was not applied #> ## Criterion 3: Adjusted: YES, Critical value: 9.925 #> ## Number of pre gain values present: 2 #> ## Number of post gain values present: 2 #> ## Mean of pre gain values: 32 #> ## Mean of post gain values: 6 #> ## SD of pre gain values: 1.414 #> ## SD of post gain values: 1.414  # Check intervall for sudden loss using all three criteria # Some missing data, alpha = 0.05 check_interval(pre_values = c(5, NA, 7),                post_values = c(16, 12, 14),                sg_crit1_cutoff = -7,                sg_crit2_pct = .25,                sg_crit3 = TRUE,                sg_crit3_alpha = .05,                identify = "sl") #> First, second, and third sudden gains criteria were applied. #> The critical value for the thrid criterion was adjusted for missingness. #> # Check sudden loss #> ## Met Criterion 1: YES #> ## Met Criterion 2: YES #> ## Met Criterion 3: YES #> ## Sudden loss: YES #>  #> # Detailed output #> ## Criterion 1: Cut-off: -7  #> ## Criterion 2: Percentage change threshhold: 25 % #> ## Criterion 3: Adjusted: YES, Critical value: 3.182 #> ## Number of pre gain values present: 2 #> ## Number of post gain values present: 3 #> ## Mean of pre gain values: 6 #> ## Mean of post gain values: 14 #> ## SD of pre gain values: 1.414 #> ## SD of post gain values: 2

what: All gains: One row per gain
title: A tutorial on using the suddengains R package
text: suddengains R package refer “bysg” (sudden gain). see code create “bysg” data set identifying sudden gains (specified using argument identify = "sg") save object called “bysg”. table shows output including following 15 new variables: id_sg: Unique identifier sudden gain sg_crit123: Logical variable indicating whether sudden gain identified sg_session_n: Pregain session number sg_freq_byperson: Frequency sudden gains identified case (id) sg_bdi_2n, sg_bdi_1n, sg_bdi_n, sg_bdi_n1, sg_bdi_n2, sg_bdi_n3: Six extracted values sudden gains measure around sudden gain sg_magnitude: Magnitude sudden gain case sg_**bdi**_tx_change: Total change sudden gains measure start (tx_start_var_name) end (tx_end_var_name) case sg_change_proportion: Magnitude sudden gain (sg_magnitude) divided total change sg_bdi_tx_change sg_reversal_value: Value representing threshold sudden gain considered ‘reversed’ sg_reversal: Logical variable indicating whether sudden gain reversed see code create “bysg” data set identifying sudden losses (specified using argument identify = "sl") save object called “bysl”. following table shows output.
code: bysg <- create_bysg(data = sgdata,                     sg_crit1_cutoff = 7,                     id_var_name = "id",                     tx_start_var_name = "bdi_s1",                     tx_end_var_name = "bdi_s12",                     sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3", "bdi_s4",                                      "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6", "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8",                                      "bdi_s9", "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),                     sg_measure_name = "bdi",                     identify = "sg") #> First, second, and third sudden gains criteria were applied. #> The critical value for the third criterion was adjusted for missingness. bysl <- create_bysg(data = sgdata,                     sg_crit1_cutoff = -7,                     id_var_name = "id",                     tx_start_var_name = "bdi_s1",                     tx_end_var_name = "bdi_s12",                     sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3", "bdi_s4",                                      "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6", "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8",                                      "bdi_s9", "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),                     sg_measure_name = "bdi",                     identify = "sl") #> First, second, and third sudden gains criteria were applied. #> The critical value for the third criterion was adjusted for missingness.

what: All cases: One row per case
title: A tutorial on using the suddengains R package
text: suddengains R package refer byperson (person). data set includes cases cases without sudden gains. multiple sudden gains experienced case, argument multiple_sg_select used specify gain selected; example first gain selected. Depending research question might interest select largest gain, shown . Notice selected gain ID 5 different depending multiple gains handled. first gain experienced ID 5 session 3 4, whereas largest gain experienced session 8 9.
code: byperson_first <- create_byperson(data = sgdata,                                   sg_crit1_cutoff = 7,                                   id_var_name = "id",                                   tx_start_var_name = "bdi_s1",                                   tx_end_var_name = "bdi_s12",                                   sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3", "bdi_s4",                                                    "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6", "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8",                                                    "bdi_s9", "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),                                   sg_measure_name = "bdi",                                   identify_sg_1to2 = FALSE,                                   multiple_sg_select = "first") #> First, second, and third sudden gains criteria were applied. #> The critical value for the third criterion was adjusted for missingness. #> The first gain/loss was selected in case of multiple gains/losses. byperson_largest <- create_byperson(data = sgdata,                                     sg_crit1_cutoff = 7,                                     id_var_name = "id",                                     tx_start_var_name = "bdi_s1",                                     tx_end_var_name = "bdi_s12",                                     sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3", "bdi_s4",                                                      "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6", "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8",                                                      "bdi_s9", "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),                                     sg_measure_name = "bdi",                                     identify_sg_1to2 = FALSE,                                     multiple_sg_select = "largest") #> First, second, and third sudden gains criteria were applied. #> The critical value for the third criterion was adjusted for missingness. #> The largest gain/loss was selected in case of multiple gains/losses.

title: A tutorial on using the suddengains R package
text: package can extract scores secondary outcome process measures around period gain. function can applied either bysg byperson dataset. Note variables specified extract_var_list must data set specified data.
code: # For bysg dataset select "id" and "rq" variables first sgdata_rq <- sgdata %>%      dplyr::select(id, rq_s0:rq_s12)  # Join them with the sudden gains data set, here "bysg" bysg_rq <- bysg %>%     dplyr::left_join(sgdata_rq, by = "id")  # Extract "rq" scores around sudden gains on "bdi" in the bysg dataset bysg_rq <- extract_values(data = bysg_rq,                           id_var_name = "id_sg",                           extract_var_list = c("rq_s1", "rq_s2", "rq_s3", "rq_s4",                                                 "rq_s5", "rq_s6", "rq_s7", "rq_s8",                                                 "rq_s9", "rq_s10", "rq_s11", "rq_s12"),                           extract_measure_name = "rq",                           add_to_data = TRUE) #> Note: The measure specified in 'extract_var_list' must have the same number of repeated time points as the measure used to identify sudden gains.

what: Plots of average change around sudden gains
title: A tutorial on using the suddengains R package
text: plots created using ggplot2 R-package (Wickham 2016) five main steps: Means time points points 95% confidence intervals time points Dotted line first two values Straight line 5 values around gain Dotted line last two values plot automatically return warning message many missing values present five components mentioned . warning messages BDI plot can interpreted follows: Means time points points: 12 missing values overall 95% confidence intervals time points: 12 missing values overall Dotted line first two values: 8 missing values session tx_start_var_name first variable specified sg_pre_post_var_list together Straight line 5 values around gain: 11 missing values together variables specified sg_pre_post_var_list Dotted line last two values: 1 missing values session tx_end_var_name last variable specified sg_pre_post_var_list
code: # Create plot of average change in depression symptoms (BDI) around the gain plot_sg_bdi <- plot_sg(data = bysg,                        id_var_name = "id",                        tx_start_var_name = "bdi_s1",                        tx_end_var_name = "bdi_s12",                        sg_pre_post_var_list = c("sg_bdi_2n", "sg_bdi_1n", "sg_bdi_n",                                                 "sg_bdi_n1", "sg_bdi_n2", "sg_bdi_n3"),                        ylab = "BDI", xlab = "Session",                        colour_single = "#239b89ff")  # Create plot of average change in rumination (RQ) around depression sudden gains plot_sg_rq <- plot_sg(data = bysg_rq,                       id_var_name = "id",                       tx_start_var_name = "rq_s1",                       tx_end_var_name = "rq_s12",                       sg_pre_post_var_list = c("sg_rq_2n", "sg_rq_1n", "sg_rq_n",                                                "sg_rq_n1", "sg_rq_n2", "sg_rq_n3"),                       ylab = "RQ", xlab = "Session",                       colour_single = "#440154FF")    # It is then possible to apply other ggplot2 functions to the plot if desired, # e.g. y axis scale, or x axis labels ...  plot_sg_bdi <- plot_sg_bdi +                 ggplot2::coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0, 50))  plot_sg_rq <- plot_sg_rq +                ggplot2::scale_x_discrete(labels = c("First", "n-2", "n-1", "n",                                                    "n+1", "n+2", "n+3", "Last")) #> Scale for x is already present. #> Adding another scale for x, which will replace the existing scale. plot_sg_bdi #> Warning: Removed 27 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_summary()`). #> Removed 27 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_summary()`). #> Warning: Removed 14 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_summary()`). #> Warning: Removed 8 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_summary()`). #> Warning: Removed 10 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_summary()`). plot_sg_rq  #> Warning: Removed 30 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_summary()`). #> Warning: Removed 30 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_summary()`). #> Warning: Removed 14 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_summary()`). #> Warning: Removed 10 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_summary()`). #> Warning: Removed 12 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_summary()`).

what: Plot average gain for multiple groups
title: A tutorial on using the suddengains R package
text: illustrate functionality create data frame grouping variable. code duplicates data frame sgdata adds variable assigning case one two groups. data frame sgdata_group can now used illustrate plotting function different groups. function works identically plot function single group. arguments used specify colours used different groups. plot shows average gain group.
code: # Set seed set.seed(123)  # Duplicate data sgdata_group <- rbind(sgdata, sgdata)  # Overwrite id variable sgdata_group$id <- c(1:86)  # Add random group variable sgdata_group$group <- sample(seq(from = 1, to = 2, by = 1), size = 86, replace = TRUE)  # Create byperson data set byperson_group <- create_byperson(data = sgdata_group,                                   sg_crit1_cutoff = 7,                                   id_var_name = "id",                                   tx_start_var_name = "bdi_s1",                                   tx_end_var_name = "bdi_s12",                                   sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3",                                                   "bdi_s4", "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6",                                                   "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8", "bdi_s9",                                                   "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),                                   sg_measure_name = "bdi",                                   multiple_sg_select = "first") #> First, second, and third sudden gains criteria were applied. #> The critical value for the third criterion was adjusted for missingness. #> The first gain/loss was selected in case of multiple gains/losses.  byperson_group_select <- select_cases(data = byperson_group,                               id_var_name = "id",                               sg_var_list what: Identify Sudden Gains in Longitudinal Data
title: Identify Sudden Gains in Longitudinal Data
text: Sudden gains large stable improvements outcome variable consecutive measurements, example psychological intervention multiple assessments (Tang DeRubeis, 1999). R package suddengains provides set tools facilitate sudden gains research. identifies sudden gains sudden losses allowing apply adaptations standard criteria. handles multiple gains creating two datasets, one structured sudden gains one participants. also implements function specify sudden gains choose case multiple gains (e.g. earliest largest gain). interactive web application shinygains illustrates main functions package allows users explore understand impact different methodological choices. learn background package see paper PLOS ONE. also created open Zotero group collecting literature looking sudden gains psychological therapies. Please let know missed anything join group add papers .

title: Identify Sudden Gains in Longitudinal Data
text: can install released version suddengains CRAN : development version GitHub :
code: install.packages("suddengains") # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("milanwiedemann/suddengains")

title: Identify Sudden Gains in Longitudinal Data
text: suddengains package comes range features can categorised : select_cases(): Select sample providing enough data identify sudden gains define_crit1_cutoff(): Uses RCI formula determine cut-value criterion 1 identify_sg(): Identifies sudden gains identify_sl(): Identifies sudden losses check_interval(): Checks given interval sudden gain/loss extract_values(): Extracts values secondary measure around sudden gain/loss create_bysg(): Creates dataset one row person create_byperson(): Creates dataset one row sudden gain/loss write_bysg(): Exports CSV, SPSS, Excel, STATA files sudden gains data sets write_byperson(): Exports CSV, SPSS, Excel, STATA files sudden gains data sets count_intervals(): Count number -session intervals available identify sudden gains plot_sg(): Creates plots average sudden gain plot_sg_trajectories(): Creates plots plots individual case trajectories plot_sg_intervals(): Plot summary available data per time point analysed session session intervals describe_sg(): Shows descriptives sudden gains datasets select_cases(): Select sample providing enough data identify sudden gains define_crit1_cutoff(): Define cut-value first SG criterion rename_sg_vars(): Rename variable names generic consistent format detailed illustration functions can found vignette CRAN. Note vignette available R install package CRAN.

title: Identify Sudden Gains in Longitudinal Data
text: identify sudden gains/losses can use identify_sg() identify_sl() functions. functions return data frame new variables indicating -session interval whether sudden gain/loss identified. example variable sg_2to3 holds information whether sudden gains occurred session two three, two pregain three postgain session. functions help identifying sudden gains listed .
code: identify_sg(data = sgdata,             sg_crit1_cutoff = 7,             sg_crit2_pct = 0.25,             sg_crit3 = TRUE,             id_var_name = "id",             sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3", "bdi_s4",                              "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6", "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8",                              "bdi_s9", "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),             identify_sg_1to2 = FALSE)

title: Identify Sudden Gains in Longitudinal Data
text: participants may experience one gain, present example, allow different subsequent analyses, package provides two options output datasets: create_bysg() function creates dataset structured one row per sudden gain, create_byperson() function creates dataset structured one row per person, indicating whether experienced sudden gain. create_bysg() function shown . functions help creating datasets analyses listed .
code: # Create output dataset with one row per sudden gain # and save as an object called "bysg" to use later bysg <- create_bysg(data = sgdata,                     sg_crit1_cutoff = 7,                     id_var_name = "id",                     tx_start_var_name = "bdi_s1",                     tx_end_var_name = "bdi_s12",                     sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3", "bdi_s4",                                      "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6", "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8",                                      "bdi_s9", "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),                     sg_measure_name = "bdi",                     identify = "sg") #> First, second, and third sudden gains criteria were applied. #> The critical value for the third criterion was adjusted for missingness.

title: Identify Sudden Gains in Longitudinal Data
text: plot_sg() function plots ‘average’ sudden gain, can used show changes around sudden gain. plot_sg_trajectories() can used visualise trajectories selection individual cases.
code: # Create plot of average change in depression symptoms (BDI) around the gain plot_sg(data = bysg,         id_var_name = "id",         tx_start_var_name = "bdi_s1",         tx_end_var_name = "bdi_s12",         sg_pre_post_var_list = c("sg_bdi_2n", "sg_bdi_1n", "sg_bdi_n",                                  "sg_bdi_n1", "sg_bdi_n2", "sg_bdi_n3"),         ylab = "BDI", xlab = "Session",         colour_single = "#239b89ff") #> Warning: Removed 27 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_summary()`). #> Removed 27 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_summary()`). #> Warning: Removed 14 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_summary()`). #> Warning: Removed 8 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_summary()`). #> Warning: Removed 10 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_summary()`). # Visualise trajectories for a selection of individual cases plot_sg_trajectories(data = sgdata,                      id_var = "id",                      select_id_list = c("2", "4", "5", "9"),                      var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3", "bdi_s4",                                    "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6", "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8",                                    "bdi_s9", "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),                      show_id = TRUE,                      id_label_size = 4,                      label.padding = .2,                      show_legend = TRUE,                      colour = "viridis",                      viridis_option = "D",                      viridis_begin = 0,                      viridis_end = 1,                      connect_missing = TRUE,                      scale_x_num = TRUE,                      scale_x_num_start = 1,                      apaish = TRUE,                      xlab = "Session",                       ylab = "BDI") #> Warning: Removed 3 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`). #> Warning: Removed 3 rows containing missing values (`geom_label_repel()`).

title: Check if a given interval is a sudden gain/loss — check_interval
code: check_interval(   pre_values,   post_values,   sg_crit1_cutoff,   sg_crit2_pct = 0.25,   sg_crit3 = TRUE,   sg_crit3_alpha = 0.05,   sg_crit3_adjust = TRUE,   sg_crit3_critical_value = 2.776,   identify = c("sg", "sl"),   details = TRUE )

title: Check if a given interval is a sudden gain/loss — check_interval
text: pre_values Vector, three pre gain/loss values checked sudden gain/loss (n-2, n-1, n) post_values Vector, three post gain/loss values checked sudden gain/loss (n+1, n+2, n+3) sg_crit1_cutoff Numeric, specifying cut-value used first sudden gains criterion. function define_crit1_cutoff can used calculate cutoff value based Reliable Change Index (RCI; Jacobson & Truax, 1991). set NULL first criterion wont applied. sg_crit2_pct Numeric, specifying percentage change used second sudden gains/losses criterion. set NULL second criterion wont applied. sg_crit3 set TRUE third criterion applied automatically adjusting critical value missingness. set FALSE third criterion wont applied. sg_crit3_alpha Numeric, alpha student t-test (two-tailed) determine critical value used third criterion. Degrees freedom based number available data three sessions preceding gain three sessions following gain. sg_crit3_adjust Logical, specify whether critical value gets adjusted missingness, see Lutz et al. (2013) documentation R package details. argument set TRUE default adjusting critical value missingness described package documentation Lutz et al. (2013): critical value 2.776 used three data points potential gain available, one data point missing either potential gain critical value 3.182 used, one data point missing gain critical value 4.303 used. set FALSE critical value 2.776 instead used comparisons, regardless missingnes sequence data points investigated sudden gains. sg_crit3_critical_value Numeric, specifying critical value instead used comparisons, regardless missingnes sequence data points investigated potential sudden gains. identify String, specifying whether identify sudden gains ("sg") sudden losses ("sl"). details Logical, details yes ?

Degrees freedom based number available data three sessions preceding gain three sessions following gain. sg_crit3_adjust Logical, specify whether critical value gets adjusted missingness, see Lutz et al. (2013) documentation R package details. argument set TRUE default adjusting critical value missingness described package documentation Lutz et al. (2013): critical value 2.776 used three data points potential gain available, one datapoint missing either potential gain critical value 3.182 used, one datapoint missing gain critical value 4.303 used (sg_crit3_alpha = 0.05). set FALSE critical value set sg_crit3_critical_value instead used comparisons, regardless missingnes sequence data points investigated potential sudden gains. sg_crit3_critical_value Numeric, specifying critical value instead used comparisons, regardless missingnes sequence data points investigated potential sudden gains.#' identify String, specifying whether identify sudden gains ("sg") using identify_sg sudden losses ("sl") using identify_sl. default identify sudden gains ("sg"). identify_sg_1to2 Logical, indicating whether identify sudden losses measurement point 1 2. set TRUE, implies first variable specified sg_var_list represents baseline measurement point, e.g. pre-intervention assessment.

what: Define cut-off value for first SG criterion — define_crit1_cutoff
title: Define cut-off value for first SG criterion — define_crit1_cutoff
text: Define cut-value first sudden gains criterion based Reliable Change Index (RCI; Jacobson & Truax, 1991) using estimate standard deviation (sd) normal population reliability scale. values can entered manually using arguments sd reliability extracted data using arguments data_sd data_reliability. function calculates standard error measurement (se), standard error difference (sdiff) value classifies reliable change (reliable_change_value) based Reliable Change Index (RCI; Jacobson & Truax, 1991). $$se = sd * \sqrt{(1 - reliability)}$$ $$sdiff = \sqrt{(2 * se^2)}$$ $$reliable change value = 1.96 * sdiff$$

title: Define cut-off value for first SG criterion — define_crit1_cutoff
code: define_crit1_cutoff(   sd = NULL,   reliability = NULL,   data_sd = NULL,   data_reliability = NULL )

title: Define cut-off value for first SG criterion — define_crit1_cutoff
text: sd Numeric, standard deviation normal population standard deviation baseline. argument needed vector pretreatment scores specified data_sd argument. reliability Numeric, 0 1 indicating reliability scale. argument needed item--item data specified data_reliability argument. data_sd vector pretreatment values. argument needed standard deviation specified sd argument. data_reliability dataset wide format (one row individual one column item) including item--item scores SG measure (ID variable). According Jacobson & Truax (1991) test-retest reliability used. Martinovich et al. (1996) suggest internal consistency (Cronbach's alpha) can used instead test-retest reliability may appropriate estimating standard error cases. argument needed reliability specified reliability argument.

title: Define cut-off value for first SG criterion — define_crit1_cutoff
text: list estimates standard error measurement (se), standard error difference (sdiff) value classifies reliable change (reliable_change_value).

title: Define cut-off value for first SG criterion — define_crit1_cutoff
text: Jacobson, N. S., & Truax, P. . (1991). Clinical significance: statistical approach defining meaningful change psychotherapy research. Journal Consulting Clinical Psychology, 59 (1), 12-19. doi:10.1037/0022-006X.59.1.12 . Martinovich, Z., Saunders, S., & Howard, K. (1996). Comments “Assessing Clinical Significance”. Psychotherapy Research, 6(2), 124–132. doi:10.1080/10503309612331331648 . Stiles et al. (2003). Early sudden gains psychotherapy routine clinic conditions: Practice-based evidence. Journal Consulting Clinical Psychology, 71 (1), 14-21. doi:10.1037/0022-006X.71.1.14 .

title: Define cut-off value for first SG criterion — define_crit1_cutoff
code: # Define cut-off value for first SG criterion # In this example the standard deviation and the reliability are specified manually define_crit1_cutoff(sd = 10.5,                     reliability = 0.931) #> The reliability of the measure used to identify sudden gains was specified in the arguement 'reliability = 0.931'. #> $sd #> [1] 10.5 #>  #> $reliability #> [1] 0.931 #>  #> $standard_error_measurement #> [1] 2.758124 #>  #> $standard_error_difference #> [1] 3.900577 #>  #> $reliable_change_value #> [1] 7.645131 #>   # In this example the reliability is specified manually # The standard deviation of the variable "bdi_s0" in the dataset "sgdata" gets calculated define_crit1_cutoff(data_sd = sgdata$bdi_s0,                     reliability = 0.931) #> The reliability of the measure used to identify sudden gains was specified in the arguement 'reliability = 0.931'. #> $sd #> [1] 6.396073 #>  #> $reliability #> [1] 0.931 #>  #> $standard_error_measurement #> [1] 1.680111 #>  #> $standard_error_difference #> [1] 2.376036 #>  #> $reliable_change_value #> [1] 4.65703 #>

title: Show descriptives for the sudden gains datasets — describe_sg
text: list, showing basic descriptive statistics sudden gains within dataset specified. Note numbers (e.g. percentages) different depending dataset selected, participant multiple gains, one selected byperson dataset. list includes values : total_n: number rows input dataset sg_total_n: total number sudden gains sg_n: number people experienced sudden gain (byperson dataset ) sg_pct: percentage people input dataset experienced sudden gain sg_multiple_n: number people experienced sudden gain (byperson dataset ) sg_multiple_pct: percentage people input dataset experienced one sudden gain sg_reversal_n: number sudden gains later meet criteria reversal sg_reversal_pct: percentage sudden gains later meet criteria reversal sg_magnitude_m: mean magnitude sudden gains observed sg_magnitude_sd: standard deviation magnitude sudden gains observed

title: Extract values around the sudden gain — extract_values
code: # Create bysg dataset bysg <- create_bysg(data = sgdata,                     sg_crit1_cutoff = 7,                     id_var_name = "id",                     tx_start_var_name = "bdi_s1",                     tx_end_var_name = "bdi_s12",                     sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3",                                     "bdi_s4", "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6",                                     "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8", "bdi_s9",                                     "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),                     sg_measure_name = "bdi") #> First, second, and third sudden gains criteria were applied. #> The critical value for the third criterion was adjusted for missingness.  # For bysg dataset select "id" and "rq" variables first sgdata_rq <- sgdata %>%   dplyr::select(id, rq_s0:rq_s12)  # Join them with the sudden gains data set, here "bysg" bysg_rq <- bysg %>%   dplyr::left_join(sgdata_rq, by = "id")  # Extract "rq" scores around sudden gains on "bdi" in the bysg dataset bysg_rq <- extract_values(data = bysg_rq,                           id_var_name = "id_sg",                           extract_var_list = c("rq_s1", "rq_s2", "rq_s3", "rq_s4",                                                "rq_s5", "rq_s6", "rq_s7", "rq_s8",                                                "rq_s9", "rq_s10", "rq_s11", "rq_s12"),                           extract_measure_name = "rq",                           add_to_data = TRUE) #> Note: The measure specified in 'extract_var_list' must have the same number of repeated time points as the measure used to identify sudden gains.

code: write_byperson(   data,   sg_crit1_cutoff,   id_var_name,   sg_var_list,   tx_start_var_name,   tx_end_var_name,   sg_measure_name,   sg_crit2_pct = 0.25,   sg_crit3 = TRUE,   sg_crit3_alpha = 0.05,   sg_crit3_adjust = TRUE,   sg_crit3_critical_value = 2.776,   identify = c("sg", "sl"),   identify_sg_1to2 = FALSE,   multiple_sg_select = c("first", "last", "smallest", "largest"),   data_is_bysg = FALSE,   format = c("CSV", "SPSS", "STATA", "Excel"),   path,   stata_version = 14,   ... )

title: Write a sudden gains data frame (byperson) to CSV, SPSS, STATA or Excel files — write_byperson
text: data data set wide format including ID variable variables measurement point. sg_crit1_cutoff Numeric, specifying cut-value used first sudden gains criterion. function define_crit1_cutoff can used calculate cutoff value based Reliable Change Index (RCI; Jacobson & Truax, 1991). set NULL first criterion wont applied. id_var_name String, specifying name ID variable. row unique value. sg_var_list Vector, specifying variable names measurement point sequentially. tx_start_var_name String, specifying variable name first measurement point intervention. tx_end_var_name String, specifying variable name last measurement point intervention. sg_measure_name String, specifying name measure used identify sudden gains/losses. sg_crit2_pct Numeric, specifying percentage change used second sudden gains/losses criterion. set NULL second criterion wont applied. sg_crit3 set TRUE third criterion applied automatically adjusting critical value missingness. set FALSE third criterion wont applied. sg_crit3_alpha Numeric, alpha student t-test (two-tailed) determine critical value used third criterion. Degrees freedom based number available data three sessions preceding gain three sessions following gain. sg_crit3_adjust Logical, specify whether critical value gets adjusted missingness, see Lutz et al. (2013) documentation R package details. argument set TRUE default adjusting critical value missingness described package documentation Lutz et al. (2013): critical value 2.776 used three data points potential gain available, one data point missing either potential gain critical value 3.182 used, one data point missing gain critical value 4.303 used (sg_crit3_alpha = 0.05). set FALSE critical value set sg_crit3_critical_value instead used comparisons, regardless missingnes sequence data points investigated potential sudden gains. sg_crit3_critical_value Numeric, specifying critical value instead used comparisons, regardless missingnes sequence data points investigated potential sudden gains.#' identify String, specifying whether identify sudden gains ("sg") using identify_sg sudden losses ("sl") using identify_sl. default identify sudden gains ("sg"). identify_sg_1to2 Logical, indicating whether identify sudden losses measurement point 1 2. multiple_sg_select String, specifying sudden gain/loss select data set one gain/loss identified per case. Options : "first", "last", "smallest", "largest", create_byperson. data_is_bysg Logical, specifying whether data set data argument bysg data set created using create_bysg function. format String, specifying format data file, "CSV", "SPSS", "STATA" "Excel". path String, specifying file name ending matching file extension, ".csv", ".sav", ".dta" ".xlsx". stata_version Numeric, specifying STATA version number. ... Additional parameters passed specified write function, see write_csv "CSV", write_sav "SPSS", write_dta "STATA" write_xlsx "Excel" information.

title: Write a sudden gains data frame (byperson) to CSV, SPSS, STATA or Excel files — write_byperson
code: # Adjust "path" argument before running # Create character string name for temporary "byperson.csv" file temp <- tempfile(pattern = "byperson", fileext = ".csv")  # Write byperson dataset (CSV file) # To write a different format change the 'format' argument ... # ... as well as the file extension in the 'path' argument write_byperson(data = sgdata,                sg_crit1_cutoff = 7,                id_var_name = "id",                tx_start_var_name = "bdi_s1",                tx_end_var_name = "bdi_s12",                sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3", "bdi_s4",                                "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6", "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8",                                "bdi_s9", "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),                sg_measure_name = "bdi",                identify_sg_1to2 = FALSE,                multiple_sg_select = "largest",                format = "CSV",                path = temp) #> First, second, and third sudden gains criteria were applied. #> The critical value for the third criterion was adjusted for missingness. #> The first gain/loss was selected in case of multiple gains/losses.

code: write_bysg(   data,   sg_crit1_cutoff,   id_var_name,   sg_var_list,   tx_start_var_name,   tx_end_var_name,   sg_measure_name,   sg_crit2_pct = 0.25,   sg_crit3 = TRUE,   sg_crit3_alpha = 0.05,   sg_crit3_adjust = TRUE,   sg_crit3_critical_value = 2.776,   identify = c("sg", "sl"),   identify_sg_1to2 = FALSE,   format = c("CSV", "SPSS", "STATA", "Excel"),   path,   stata_version = 14,   ... )

title: Write a sudden gains data frame (bysg) to CSV, SPSS, STATA or Excel files — write_bysg
text: data data set wide format including ID variable variables measurement point. sg_crit1_cutoff Numeric, specifying cut-value used first sudden gains criterion. function define_crit1_cutoff can used calculate cutoff value based Reliable Change Index (RCI; Jacobson & Truax, 1991). set NULL first criterion wont applied. id_var_name String, specifying name ID variable. row unique value. sg_var_list Vector, specifying variable names measurement point sequentially. tx_start_var_name String, specifying variable name first measurement point intervention. tx_end_var_name String, specifying variable name last measurement point intervention. sg_measure_name String, specifying name measure used identify sudden gains/losses. sg_crit2_pct Numeric, specifying percentage change used second sudden gains/losses criterion. set NULL second criterion wont applied. sg_crit3 set TRUE third criterion applied automatically adjusting critical value missingness. set FALSE third criterion wont applied. sg_crit3_alpha Numeric, alpha student t-test (two-tailed) determine critical value used third criterion. Degrees freedom based number available data three sessions preceding gain three sessions following gain. sg_crit3_adjust Logical, specify whether critical value gets adjusted missingness, see Lutz et al. (2013) documentation R package details. argument set TRUE default adjusting critical value missingness described package documentation Lutz et al. (2013): critical value 2.776 used three data points potential gain available, one data point missing either potential gain critical value 3.182 used, one data point missing gain critical value 4.303 used (sg_crit3_alpha = 0.05). set FALSE critical value set sg_crit3_critical_value instead used comparisons, regardless missingnes sequence data points investigated potential sudden gains. sg_crit3_critical_value Numeric, specifying critical value instead used comparisons, regardless missingnes sequence data points investigated potential sudden gains. identify String, specifying whether identify sudden gains ("sg") using identify_sg sudden losses ("sl") using identify_sl. default identify sudden gains ("sg"). identify_sg_1to2 Logical, indicating whether identify sudden losses measurement point 1 2. format String, specifying format data file, "CSV", "SPSS", "STATA" "Excel". path String, specifying file name ending matching file extension, ".csv", ".sav", ".dta" ".xlsx". stata_version Numeric, specifying STATA version number. ... Additional parameters passed specified write function, see write_csv "CSV", write_sav "SPSS", write_dta "STATA" write_xlsx "Excel" information.

title: Write a sudden gains data frame (bysg) to CSV, SPSS, STATA or Excel files — write_bysg
text: Tang, T. Z., & DeRubeis, R. J. (1999). Sudden gains critical sessions cognitive-behavioral therapy depression. Journal Consulting Clinical Psychology, 67(6), 894–904. doi:10.1037/0022-006X.67.6.894 .

title: Write a sudden gains data frame (bysg) to CSV, SPSS, STATA or Excel files — write_bysg
code: # Adjust "path" argument before running # Create character string name for temporary "bysg.csv" file temp <- tempfile(pattern = "bysg", fileext = ".csv")  # Write bysg dataset (CSV file) # To write a different format change the 'format' argument # as well as the file extension in the 'path' argument write_bysg(data = sgdata,            sg_crit1_cutoff = 7,            id_var_name = "id",            tx_start_var_name = "bdi_s1",            tx_end_var_name = "bdi_s12",            sg_var_list = c("bdi_s1", "bdi_s2", "bdi_s3", "bdi_s4",                            "bdi_s5", "bdi_s6", "bdi_s7", "bdi_s8",                            "bdi_s9", "bdi_s10", "bdi_s11", "bdi_s12"),            sg_measure_name = "bdi",            identify_sg_1to2 = FALSE,            format = "CSV",            path = temp) #> First, second, and third sudden gains criteria were applied. #> The critical value for the third criterion was adjusted for missingness.
